awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Enhancing Middle Grades Students' Capacity to Develop and Communicate Their Mathematical Understanding of Big Ideas Using Digital Inscriptional Resources
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary goal of this project is to help middle school students deepen and communicate their understanding of mathematics. The project will develop and test a digital platform for middle school mathematics classrooms. The digital platform will allow students to collaboratively create representations of their mathematics thinking, incorporate ideas from other students, and share their work with the class. The digital learning environment makes use of a problem-centered mathematics curriculum that evolved from extensive development, field-testing and evaluation, and is widely used in middle schools. The research will also contribute to understanding about the design and innovative use of digital resources and collaboration in classrooms as an increasing number of schools are drawing on these kinds of tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The project will support students to collaboratively construct, manipulate, and interpret shared representations of mathematics using digital inscriptional resources. The research activities will significantly enhance our understanding of student learning in mathematics in three important ways. The project will report on how (1) evidence of student thinking is made visible through the use of digital inscriptional resources, (2) student inscriptions are documented, discussed, and manipulated in collaborative settings, and (3) students' conceptual growth of big mathematical ideas grows over time. An iterative design research process will incorporate four phases of development, testing and revision, and will be conducted to study student use of the digital learning space and related inscriptional resources. Data sources will include: classroom observations and artifacts, student and teacher interviews and surveys, student assessment data, and analytics from the digital platform. The process will include close collaboration with teachers to understand the implementation and create revisions to the resources.

por.por_cntn:
Enhancing Middle Grades Students? Capacity to Develop and Communicate Their Mathematical Understanding of Big Ideas Using Digital Inscriptional Resources

Project Outcomes Report

Knowing how students develop and communicate their understanding of big mathematical ideas is critically important for researchers, teachers, and curriculum developers. As students learn, particularly when they do so by working together in collaborative group settings, they create and make use of inscriptions of their thinking, such as written text, graphical displays, tables, equations, and diagrams. Sharing, combining, and modifying such inscriptions as they work together is an important aspect of students' collaborative learning. Understanding how students create and use these inscriptions and how they evolve over time provides important insight into the processes of learning and ways to better support learning in different contexts.

The project engaged in cycles of design, development, classroom testing, analysis, and refinement to develop inscriptional resources in a digital collaborative platform. To support a smooth transition to problem-solving in the digital environment, students have dedicated inscriptional workspaces that are adjacent to the embedded problems from the Connected Mathematics Project (CMP). Elements of the CMP problem (text, images, graphs, tables, etc.) can be dragged into workspaces where they are converted into interactive resources that can be arranged and modified. A four-up student workspace was developed, where up to four student individual workspaces are shown on the screen at the same time. This allows students to see their own work and see what their group members are doing in real time. With this feature, students can share their work with each other, discuss problem-solving strategies, and assign parts of the problem to individuals, and then combine their strategies into a complete solution that can be shared with the class. Students in their small groups can also publish work to other groups and use it during whole-group discussions. The learning log workspace persists across problems and units, allowing students to collect, revise, and combine mathematical inscriptions. Students can revisit inscriptions from prior problems and drag them into their workspace, supporting students? capacity to build on prior thinking and make connections when they encounter new situations. These entries allow students to revisit, reuse, refine, and consolidate their mathematical thinking over time. For teachers, the project platform includes features to support students in their work with inscriptions. A teacher dashboard allows teachers to (a) monitor digital inscriptions of student thinking in real-time, (b) quickly scan and select student inscriptions for possible inclusion in whole-class discussions, (c) mark-up and incorporate student work into a classroom inscription that reflects the mathematics thinking of the class, and (d) publish class inscriptions for students to incorporate into their individual learning logs. The platform and its developed features are currently being used in mathematics and science education research projects.

This project investigated the student inscriptional practices in mathematics that are exhibited during collaborative work in small groups. From the perspective of inscriptions, the meaning of a representation shifts and evolves over time as students produce and reproduce them in a continuous meaning-making process. Using video recordings, computer screen recordings, teacher interviews, and student interviews/surveys, the project generated knowledge about the nature of student inscriptional practices for problems in the CMP curriculum. The project team expanded on the concept of inscriptional practices and created an analytic framework that can describe how three types of student inscriptional practices in mathematics are carried out in digital environments. These three types of inscriptional practices included constructing, communicating, and circulating (sharing and/or retrieving). While prior research has largely focused on the construction of inscriptions, our project research found that in the digital collaborative environment, students in their small groups simultaneously engaged in the inscriptional practices of communicating and circulating. Students considered the digital inscriptions of their peers and their conversations around these inscriptions as they used the digital resources to create their own mathematical representations. The research team also looked for patterns of inscriptional practices from different small groups and found that students inscriptional practices typically differed for each problem. These findings suggests that individual and groups of students do not use the digital platform and its features in the same ways and suggests that the digital resources can provide teachers with new supports for students as they collaboratively explore and solve mathematics problems. Therefore, the research findings provide insights into to how schools use technology resources to enhance the learning of mathematics, particularly in small group collaborations where complex mathematical inscriptions are constructed, discussed, and shared among students and their teachers. Knowledge from the project has been disseminated through journal articles, research presentations, and newsletters
